definitions.definition: having a lower than usual temperature; having a temperature lower than the human body

examples.text: I'm cold. Turn the heating up.
to feel cold
**cold weather/temperatures/air**
a **cold day/night/winter/wind**
a cold room/house
cold hands and feet
a cold beer
**hot and cold** running water in every room
I was thoroughly **cold and wet** now.
It's **freezing cold**.
Hurry up—your dinner's **getting cold**
a **bitterly cold** morning
You look cold. Do you want to go back indoors?
Isn't it cold today?
It has suddenly turned very cold.
the coldest May on record
The water has gone cold.
I'm afraid the coffee's gone cold.
In January it turned very cold.
It's bitterly cold outside.
The rain overnight had made the water cold.
The room grew cold.
There was a freezing cold wind.
Use ice to keep the drinks cold.
Your dinner's getting cold.
It grew colder as the evening came.
It was the coldest winter on record.
The stream was icy cold.

definitions.definition: not heated; cooled after being cooked

examples.text: a cold drink
Hot and cold food is available in the cafeteria.
Bake in the oven for twenty minutes. Serve hot or cold.
It's cold chicken for lunch.
a lunch of cold meat and salad
to give somebody a cold look/stare
Her manner was cold and distant.
He was staring at her with cold eyes.
She was very cold towards me.
He received a cold welcome.
I found him a rather cold person.
He was portrayed as a cold, calculating terrorist.
She gave David a cold look of disapproval.

definitions.definition: seeming to lack any warm feeling, in an unpleasant way

examples.text: clear cold light
cold grey skies
The police followed the robbers to the airport but then the **trail went cold**.

definitions.definition: used in children’s games to say that the person playing is not close to finding a person or thing, or to guessing the correct answer

examples.text: He was knocked out cold in the second round.

definitions.definition: facts with nothing added to make them more interesting or pleasant
to change your opinion about something often
a person who seems unfriendly and without strong emotions
to suddenly become nervous about doing something that you had planned to do

examples.text: He was going to ask her but he got cold feet and said nothing.

definitions.definition: to treat somebody in a way that is not friendly
to experience a sudden feeling of fear or worry

examples.text: When the phone rang I just went hot and cold.

definitions.definition: acting in a way that is deliberately cruel

examples.text: to kill somebody in cold blood

definitions.definition: when you have had time to think calmly about something; in the morning when things are clearer

examples.text: These things always look different in the cold light of day.

definitions.definition: to fail to affect or interest somebody

examples.text: Most modern art leaves me cold.

definitions.definition: to make somebody very frightened or fill them with horror

examples.text: The sound of laughter in the empty house made my blood run cold.
Our blood ran cold at the thought of how easily we could have been killed.

definitions.definition: to give reasons for not being in favour of something; to criticize something

examples.text: She immediately poured cold water on his plans to expand the business.

wordOrigin: Old English cald, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch koud and German kalt, also to Latin gelu ‘frost’.
